facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 372 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 372 of 1960. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated April 6, 1955 of the former High Court of Travancore-Cochin in Appeal Suit No. 721 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 6, 1955, of the former High Court of Travancore-Cochin in Appeal Suit No. 721 of 1951.

facts.text: Travancore-Cochin High Court allowed the appeal preferred by the respondents from the decree of the District Court of Parur dismissing their suit.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment of the Travancore-Cochin High Court which allowed the appeal preferred by the respondents from the decree of the District Court of Parur dismissing their suit for declaration of title to and recovery of possession of certain properties and for other companysequential reliefs.

facts.text: 23 items of property comprised in the schedule to the plaint belonged originally to Ramalinga Iyer and Raman Velayudhan.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts are as follows The 23 items of property companyprised in the schedule to the plaint belonged originally to two persons Ramalinga Iyer  Iyer as described by the High Court  and Raman Velayudhan.

facts.text: Ramalinga Iyer and Raman Velayudhan sold the 23 items on 6-6-1080 Malayalam Era (roughly 1905) to Ittivavira, father of appellant-defendant No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: They sold them on  6-6-1080  Malayalam Era which roughly companyresponds to the year 1905  to Ittivavira the deceased father of the appellant-defendant No. 1.

facts.text: Ittivavira executed two hypothecation bonds on the same date for balance consideration.

anchor.surface_text: Part of the companysideration for the sale was paid by Ittiyavira in cash and for the balance, he executed two hypothecation bonds in favour his vendors on the same date.

facts.text: One hypothecation bond to Raman Velayudhan for Rs. 308-8-0, hypothecating items 3,5,14,18.

anchor.surface_text: One of the bonds was executed in favour of Raman Velayudhan and the amount secured thereunder was Rs. 308-8-0. In respect of this amount, items of property Nos. 3, 5, 14 and 18 were hypothecated with Raman Velayudhan by Ittiyavira.

facts.text: Other bond to Ramalinga Iyer for Rs. 2,191-8-0, hypothecating other items.

anchor.surface_text: The other bond was in favour of Ramalinga Iyer and under this bond. Ittiyavira hypothecated with him items Nos. 1, 2, 4, 6-13, 151-7, and 19-23 and also the remaining items, subject to the hypothecation bond in favour of Raman Velavudhan, for securing an amount of Rs.2,191-80

facts.text: On 3-10-1082, Ramalinga Iyer assigned his hypothecation bond to Sankara Rama Iyer (Ex. V), disputed as sham.

anchor.surface_text: On 3-1.0-1082, Ramalinga Iyer assigned his hypothecation bond in favour of one Sankara Rama Iyer  Iyen as described by the High Court . The parties are in dispute companycerning this transaction.

facts.text: Anantha Iyer obtained decree Ex. VI on 13-11-1088 against Sankara Subha Iyer.

anchor.surface_text: After the death of Ramalinga Iyer, Anantha Iyer instituted a suit against his son Sankara Subha Iyer  lyen as described by the High Court  for recovery of the amount thereunder and obtained a decree Ex. VI on 13-11-1088.

facts.text: Anantha Iyer attached and purchased Ramalinga Iyer's mortgagee rights at court auction.

anchor.surface_text: Treating the deed of assignment executed by Ramalinga Iyer in favour of Sankara Rama Iyer as a sham document, Anantha Iyer attached the mortgagee rights of Ramalinga Iyer in the hypothecation bond which had been executed in his favour by Ittiyavira. The rights under this bond were sold in execution and were purchased by Anantha Iyer at companyrt auction.

facts.text: In partition, rights allotted to Anantha Iyer and brother Manicka Iyer.

anchor.surface_text: In a subsequent partition in Anantha Iyers family, the rights under the hypothecation bond purchased in execution by him were allotted to his share and that of his brother Manicka Iyer  Iyen as described by the High Court .

facts.text: Anantha and Manicka Iyer instituted O.S. No. 59 of 1093 against Ittivavira and obtained decree.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, these two persons instituted a suit against Ittivavira being O. S. No. 59 of 1093 in the District Court at Parur and obtained a decree for realisation of the amount against Ittivavira.

facts.text: Decree transferred to Venkiteswara Iyer, who purchased properties at auction on 27-4-1099 (Ex. C).

anchor.surface_text: The decree- holders subsequently transferred their decree to one Venkiteswara Iyer  Iyen as described by the High Court  which the latter executed and at the companyrt auction held in execution of that decree, he himself purchased the hypothecated properties which are the properties in the suit on 27-4-1099. Exhibit C is the sale certificate which was granted to him by the companyrt.

facts.text: Venkiteswara Iyer obtained possession on 12-7-1099.

anchor.surface_text: Venkiteswara Iyer eventually obtained possession of the properties on 12-7-1099.

facts.text: Ittiyavira executed sale deed to appellant (son) on 8-10-1092 (Ex. XXIX), disputed as sham.

anchor.surface_text: Even before the institution of O. S. 59 of 1093 by Anantha Iyer and his brother, Ittiyavira had executed a sale deed in favour of his son the appellant before us-whereunder, he companyveyed to him all the properties in the suit. The date on which the sale deed was executed was 8-10-1092.

facts.text: Venkiteswara Iyer sold suit properties to plaintiffs-respondents on 2-2-1108.

anchor.surface_text: Ittiyavira died in the year 1107 and on 2-2-1108, Venkiteswara Iyer sold all the suitproperties to the plaintiffs-respondents.

facts.text: Respondents instituted s.145 CrPC proceedings, magistrate held appellant in possession, affirmed by Travancore HC.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the respondents instituted proceecdings under s. 145 of the Code of Criminal Procedure in the companyrt of the Magistrate, First Class, Perumbavoor... Eventually, the companyrt held that the properties were in the possession of the appellant and ordered that his possession be maintained until otherwise ordered by a companypetent Civil Court. The order of the Magistrate was affirmed by the Travancore High Court

facts.text: District Court Parur dismissed suit, High Court reversed except items 3,5,14,18.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt dismissed the suit. The High Court, however, reversed the decree of the trial companyrt except with respect to items 3, 5, 4 and 18 in the plaint.

facts.text: Appellant claims sale by Ittiyavira to him is genuine, respondents claim sham.

anchor.surface_text: Their companytention in the suit is that the alleged sale by Ittiyavira in favour of the appellant is a sham transaction

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Ex. V (assignment) is sham.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the observations of the High Court and would add that this circumstance as well as the omission of the appellant to examine any person directly companynected with the execution proceedings would justify an inference that the transaction evidenced by Ex. V is number a genuine one and that the document itself is sham and bogus.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Ex. XXIX (sale to appellant) is sham.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, agree with the High Court that Ex. XXIX was a sham and bogus document and that the transaction evidenced by it is number genuine.

facts.text: Actual delivery of possession to auction-purchaser Venkiteswara Iyer on 12-7-1099.

anchor.surface_text: we hold that there can be numberdoubt that actual delivery of possession of the suit properties was effected by the Amin to the auction-purchaser on 12-7-1099.

An appeal lay to the High Court and the appeal in question was in fact heard, and disposed by the High Court and, therefore, numberright of the party has been infringed merely because it was heard by two judges and number by three judges.

issues.text: whether the decree in O. S. No. 59 of 1093 obtained by Anantha Iyer and his brother in the suit on the hypothecation bond executed by Ittiyavira in favour of Ramalinga Iyer was a nullity because the suit was barred by time

anchor.surface_text: The first point raised by Mr. Paikedy for the appellant is that the decree in O. S. No. 59 of 1093 obtained by Anantha Iyer and his brother in the suit on the hypothecation bond executed by Ittiyavira in favour of Ramalinga Iyer was a nullity because the suit was barred by time. Even assuming that the suit was barred by time, it is difficult to appreciate the contention of learned counsel that the decree can be treated as a nullity and ignored in subsequent litigation.

issues.text: whether the present suit was barred because it was not instituted within three years of the decision of the Magistrate, First Class, Perumbavoor, holding that the appellant was in possession of the suit properties

anchor.surface_text: The next point raised by learned counsel is that the present suit was barred because it was not instituted within three years of the decision of the Magistrate, First Class, Perumbavoor, holding that the appellant was in possession of the suit properties. It is no doubt true that the order in question was passed on 28-12-1111 while the suit was instituted in the District Court, Parur on 4-3-1118

issues.text: whether the suit is governed by Art. 142 of the Limitation Act and as the respondents have not established that they were in possession within 12 years thereof, their suit is barred by time

anchor.surface_text: The next contention of the learned counsel is that the suit is governed by Art. 142 of the Limitation Act and as the respondents have not established that they were in possession within 12 years thereof, their suit is barred by time. This plea of the appellant rests upon another contention which is that the delivery of possession to the auction-purchaser in O. S. No. 59 of 1093 was a sham and fraudulent transaction.

issues.text: whether Anantha Iyer and his brother got no rights by reason of the attachment and sale of the hypothecation bond executed by Ittiyavira in favour of Ramalinga Iyer because long before their purchase, Ramalinga Iyer had assigned that bond to Sankara Rama Iyer

anchor.surface_text: The next point urged by learned counsel is that Anantha Iyer and his brother got no rights by reason of the attachment and sale of the hypothecation bond executed by Ittiyavira in favour of Ramalinga Iyer because long before their purchase, Ramalinga Iyer had assigned that bond to Sankara Rama Iyer. The contention of the respondent is that Ex. V under which the alleged assignment was made is a sham document executed by Ramalinga Iyer in order to screen the hypothecation bond from his creditors and to preserve the amount thereunder for his own benefit.

issues.text: whether the appellant is not bound by the decree in O. S. No. 59 of 1093, because he was not made a party thereto

anchor.surface_text: The next and the last point urged by learned counsel is that the appellant is not bound by the decree in O. S. No. 59 of 1093, because he was not made a party thereto. If in fact the assignment of the properties by Ittiyavira in favour of the appellant was a genuine one, the appellants contention would have to be upheld.

issues.text: whether the appeal before the High Court should have been heard not by a Division Bench of merely two judges, but by a Bench of three judges, as provided in s. 11(1) of the Travancore High Court Act, 1099

anchor.surface_text: Having thus failed on all the contentions on merits, learned counsel has sought to urge a new point before us. The point is that the appeal before the High Court should have been heard not by a Division Bench of merely two judges, but by a Bench of three judges, as provided in s. 11 1 of the Travancore High Court Act. 1099 IV of 1099.

arguments.claim: s. 3 of the Limitation Act is peremptory and court acts without jurisdiction if fails to notice it

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel, however, referred us to the decision of the Privy Council in Maqbul Ahmed v. Onkar Pratap Narain, and contended that since the court is bound under the provisions of s. 3 of the Limitation Act to ascertain for itself whether the suit before it was within time, it would act without jurisdiction if it fails to do so.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: edings under s. 145 of the Code of Criminal Procedure but the plaint was returned for presentation to the proper companyrt, they would be entitled und

arguments.court_reasoning: Privy Council holds duty to notice, but failure is error of law, not lack of jurisdiction; correctable per CPC.

anchor.surface_text: The trial court dismissed the suit. The High Court, however, reversed the decree of the trial court except with respect to items 3, 5, 14 and 18 in the plaint.

arguments.court_reasoning: SC affirms HC reversal for most items.

arguments.claim: High Court reversed trial court except items 3,5,14,18

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, reversed the decree of the trial court except with respect to items 3, 5, 14 and 18 in the plaint.

arguments.court_reasoning: SC agrees with HC findings on shams and possession.

holdings.text: A decree passed by a court having jurisdiction over the subject-matter and parties is not a nullity even if the suit was barred by limitation under s.3 Limitation Act; failure to notice limitation is error of law, correctable by appeal, not lack of jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The first point raised by Mr. Paikedy for the appellant is that the decree in O. S. No. 59 of 1093 obtained by Anantha Iyer and his brother in the suit on the hypothecation bond executed by Ittiyavira in favour of Ramalinga Iyer was a nullity because the suit was barred by time. Even assuming that the suit was barred by time, it is difficult to appreciate the contention of learned counsel that the decree can be treated as a nullity and ignored in subsequent litigation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court with jurisdiction deciding wrongly commits error of law, not jurisdictional error; cites Privy Council distinguishing duty from jurisdiction; decree binding unless set aside on appeal.

holdings.text: Appellant not permitted to raise plea that suit barred by limitation computed from Magistrate's s.145 CrPC order as point not raised in lower courts, no clear plea in written statement, mixed question of fact/law, no specific ground in certificate petition.

anchor.surface_text: The next point raised by learned counsel is that the present suit was barred because it was not instituted within three years of the decision of the Magistrate, First Class, Perumbavoor, holding that the appellant was in possession of the suit properties. It is no doubt true that the order in question was passed on 28-12-1111 while the suit was instituted in the District Court, Parur on 4-3-1118

holdings.reasoning_summary: No clear plea or issue finding in trial court; suit instituted timely in Munsiff court, returned under s.14 Limitation Act; declined in SC as new point.

holdings.text: Actual delivery of possession of suit properties effected to auction-purchaser Venkiteswara Iyer on 12-7-1099; not merely symbolical; s.145 CrPC finding of appellant's possession limited to date of preliminary order; receiver's possession enures to true owner; suit within Art.142 Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: The next contention of the learned counsel is that the suit is governed by Art. 142 of the Limitation Act and as the respondents have not established that they were in possession within 12 years thereof, their suit is barred by time. This plea of the appellant rests upon another contention which is that the delivery of possession to the auction-purchaser in O. S. No. 59 of 1093 was a sham and fraudulent transaction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court records (Ex.D) show actual possession; presumption of regularity; PW2/PW3 testify to actual delivery; no proof of obstruction; s.145 possession as of preliminary date only; receiver possession benefits rightful owner.

holdings.text: Assignment deed Ex.V by Ramalinga Iyer to Sankara Rama Iyer is sham and bogus; conveys no rights; execution sale validly transferred hypothecation rights to Anantha Iyer.

anchor.surface_text: The next point urged by learned counsel is that Anantha Iyer and his brother got no rights by reason of the attachment and sale of the hypothecation bond executed by Ittiyavira in favour of Ramalinga Iyer because long before their purchase, Ramalinga Iyer had assigned that bond to Sankara Rama Iyer. The contention of the respondent is that Ex. V under which the alleged assignment was made is a sham document executed by Ramalinga Iyer in order to screen the hypothecation bond from his creditors and to preserve the amount thereunder for his ownbenefit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ramalinga retrieved document post-registration; no enforcement by assignee for 32 years; fictitious debts/consideration; no evidence of payments/debts; agrees with High Court.

holdings.text: Sale deed Ex.XXIX by Ittivavira to appellant (son) is sham and bogus; appellant not bound by decree in O.S.59/1093 as no genuine rights acquired thereunder.

anchor.surface_text: The next and the last point urged by learned counsel is that the appellant is not bound by the decree in O. S. No. 59 of 1093, because he was not made a party thereto. If in fact the assignment of the properties by Ittiyavira in favour of the appellant was a genuine one, the appellants contention would have to be upheld.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suspicious recitals; no proof of consideration payments; son minor/no independent means; father continued as owner; appellant's possession benami/agency.

holdings.text: Appeal before Travancore-Cochin High Court validly heard and decided by Division Bench of two judges; no vested right in specific number of judges or pre-merger procedure.

anchor.surface_text: Having thus failed on all the contentions on merits, learned counsel has sought to urge a new point before us. The point is that the appeal before the High Court should have been heard not by a Division Bench of merely two judges, but by a Bench of three judges, as provided in s. 11(1) of the Travancore High Court Act, 1099 (IV of 1099).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural matter post-merger/repeal; new High Court substituted rights; no vested right in bench size; appeal heard/disposed validly.

precedents.citation: Maqbul -Ahmed v. Onkar Pratap Narain 1 , A.I.R. 1935 P.C. 83.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel, however, referred us to the decision of the Privy Council in Maqbul -Ahmed v. Onkar Pratap Narain 1 , and contended that since the court is bound under the provisions of s. 3 of the Limitation Act to ascertain for itself whether the suit before it was within time, it would act without jurisdiction if it fails to do so. Act that the decision relied upon says that s. 3 of the Limitation Act is peremptory

precedents.case_name: Maqbul Ahmed v. Onkar Pratap Narain
precedents.cited_proposition: Section 3 of the Limitation Act is peremptory and the court has a duty to take notice of limitation even if not pleaded in the pleadings.
precedents.cited_holding: s. 3 of the Limitation Act is peremptory and that it is the duty of the court to take notice of this provision and give effect to it even though the point of limitation is not referred to in the pleadings.

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: We therefore overrule the companytention of the learned companynsel and hold that the appeal was rightly heard and decided by a Bench of two judges.

outcome.relief_summary: Appellant's appeal dismissed; all contentions rejected; High Court judgment affirmed, declaring respondents' title to and possession of the suit properties (remaining items excluding 3,5,14,18)

edges.explanation: Holding directly addresses and resolves the issue of whether the decree was a nullity.

anchor.surface_text: The first point raised by Mr. Paikedy for the appellant is that the decree in O. S. No. 59 of 1093 obtained by Anantha Iyer and his brother in the suit on the hypothecation bond executed by Ittiyavira in favour of Ramalinga Iyer was a nullity because the suit was barred by time. Even assuming that the suit was barred by time, it is difficult to appreciate the contention of learned counsel that the decree can be treated as a nullity and ignored in subsequent litigation.
We therefore overrule the companytention of the learned companynsel and hold that the appeal was rightly heard and decided by a Bench of two judges.
ke this in the present suit, alter the lapse of a long period since the 2nd defendants brother took possession of the properties in execution proceedi

edges.explanation: Holding h2 addresses issue i2 by rejecting appellant's limitation plea computed from Magistrate's s.145 CrPC order due to procedural reasons.

anchor.surface_text: The next point raised by learned counsel is that the present suit was barred because it was not instituted within three years of the decision of the Magistrate, First Class, Perumbavoor, holding that the appellant was in possession of the suit properties. It is no doubt true that the order in question was passed on 28-12-1111 while the suit was instituted in the District Court, Parur on 4-3-1118
We therefore overrule the companytention of the learned companynsel and hold that the appeal was rightly heard and decided by a Bench of two judges.

anchor.surface_text: The next contention of the learned counsel is that the suit is governed by Art. 142 of the Limitation Act and as the respondents have not established that they were in possession within 12 years thereof, their suit is barred by time. This plea of the appellant rests upon another contention which is that the delivery of possession to the auction-purchaser in O. S. No. 59 of 1093 was a sham and fraudulent transaction.
We therefore overrule the companytention of the learned companynsel and hold that the appeal was rightly heard and decided by a Bench of two judges.

anchor.surface_text: The next point urged by learned counsel is that Anantha Iyer and his brother got no rights by reason of the attachment and sale of the hypothecation bond executed by Ittiyavira in favour of Ramalinga Iyer because long before their purchase, Ramalinga Iyer had assigned that bond to Sankara Rama Iyer. The contention of the respondent is that Ex. V under which the alleged assignment was made is a sham document executed by Ramalinga Iyer in order to screen the hypothecation bond from his creditors and to preserve the amount thereunder for his ownbenefit.
We therefore overrule the companytention of the learned companynsel and hold that the appeal was rightly heard and decided by a Bench of two judges.

anchor.surface_text: The next and the last point urged by learned counsel is that the appellant is not bound by the decree in O. S. No. 59 of 1093, because he was not made a party thereto. If in fact the assignment of the properties by Ittiyavira in favour of the appellant was a genuine one, the appellants contention would have to be upheld.
We therefore overrule the companytention of the learned companynsel and hold that the appeal was rightly heard and decided by a Bench of two judges.

anchor.surface_text: Having thus failed on all the contentions on merits, learned counsel has sought to urge a new point before us. The point is that the appeal before the High Court should have been heard not by a Division Bench of merely two judges, but by a Bench of three judges, as provided in s. 11(1) of the Travancore High Court Act, 1099 (IV of 1099).
We therefore overrule the companytention of the learned companynsel and hold that the appeal was rightly heard and decided by a Bench of two judges.
